verses.text: When the men of Israel saw the army of Holofernes fleeing, they rushed after them, pursuing them down the mountain.
verses.comment: The victory occurs by God’s intervention, similar to other Old Testament battles where the Israelites pursue fleeing enemies. The text emphasizes active cooperation with God after the miraculous event.

verses.text: The people of Bethulia came out and took control of the surrounding area, seizing the abandoned Assyrian camp, and carrying away great spoils.
verses.comment: Just as after Jericho (Joshua 6:24), Israel receives both victory and material blessings, hinting at divine providence for those who trust and persevere in faith.

verses.text: Then the Israelite soldiers, returning from the slaughter, seized the rest of the Assyrians, and those who escaped out of the region were utterly destroyed.
verses.comment: Total victory is again shown, echoing the biblical motif of complete deliverance, reminding believers of the assurance of God’s saving power for His people.

verses.text: Then Joakim, the high priest, and the elders of Israel living in Jerusalem came to see what God had done for Israel, to witness Judith and to greet her.
verses.comment: The mention of the high priest and elders coming together reflects the unity and central leadership in worship and thanksgiving, a strong lesson in honoring spiritual authority and community.

verses.text: As soon as they verified all Holofernes had done and seen how God had delivered Israel, they praised Judith and joined in thanksgiving with all the people.
verses.comment: Note the organized praise and thanksgiving—public, liturgical celebration—echoing patterns seen throughout Scripture that highlight the importance of corporate worship after divine intervention.

verses.text: All the women of Israel ran together to see her, and they blessed her, dancing in her honor. She received olive branches from them and made wreaths for herself.
verses.comment: Olive branches and wreaths symbolize peace, victory, and blessedness. The women’s role here highlights both leadership and celebration within the community, pointing to the dignity of God-fearing women in biblical salvation history.

verses.text: With one voice, the men of Israel sang songs of thanksgiving for her, and the city celebrated her victory.
verses.comment: The united song evokes the tradition of Miriam’s and Deborah’s songs—women’s prominent role in leading worship and thanksgiving after national deliverance (Exodus 15:20-21; Judges 5:1-31).

verses.text: Joakim and all the elders of Israel visited her, acknowledging that she was blessed among women by God, and all the people honored her.
verses.comment: Judith is blessed among women—language reminiscent of Gabriel’s and Elizabeth’s greetings to Mary (Luke 1:28, 42). The typological connection here points to the spiritual honor given to those chosen for God’s purposes.

verses.text: Joakim said to her, 'You have brought salvation to our nation. You have done what no man could, and have walked in the way of God with uprightness.'
verses.comment: Her actions are described in salvific terms—bringing salvation, acting righteously—foreshadowing the greater salvation brought by Christ who worked what no man could (John 1:17).

verses.text: All the people said, 'So be it!' and celebrated Judith for many days. She bestowed gifts upon women, and the men kept her memory in their songs and praises.
verses.comment: Remembering and praising those holy servants has deep roots in Scripture—‘Your name will be remembered’ (Ps. 45:17)—indicating the importance of venerating faithful leaders and the communal telling of salvation history.

verses.text: When the feast ended, every man returned to his own inheritance, and Judith remained in Bethulia. She kept her honor all her days.
verses.comment: Judith’s enduring honor and the people returning to their inheritance recall God’s promise to Israel to dwell securely in their land—fulfilling covenant blessings through faith and obedience.

verses.text: As long as she lived, none threatened Israel, and many continued to remember her goodness year after year.
verses.comment: Her life brings a time of peace to Israel, similar to how judges and prophets secured periods of rest for God’s people. Judith’s legacy operates as an ongoing deliverance, a prefigurement of more lasting salvation.

verses.text: After Judith, the people kept celebrating her victory, passing her story down through generations.
verses.comment: Perpetuating the memory and honor of holy figures, as seen elsewhere in Scripture, is a tradition of acknowledging God’s work through His chosen servants, encouraging continued faithfulness over time.

verses.text: And Judith herself dedicated all spoils and gifts she received to the sanctuary, to God as a perpetual offering.
verses.comment: Judith’s act of dedicating everything to God expresses both physical and spiritual worship, elevating sacrificial giving modeled by the holiest figures of Scripture, prefiguring Christ’s total self-gift to God (Heb. 9:14).
